item.title: Fediverse: An overview for community organizers
item.dc:creator: Stefan Bohacek
item.description: Fediverse as a tool for communities and community organizers.
item.content:encoded:
Table of Contents

  • What is the fediverse
  • How to create a fediverse community
  • Moderation resources
  • Fediverse tools
  • Case studies
    • The Forkiverse
  • Why not the Atmosphere?
  • See also

What is the fediverse

Fediverse is a grassroot effort to empower people to connect online without Big Tech CEOs controlling what they can post and venture capital companies pouring in money and hoping for a big payout one day at the price of enshittification.

Fediverse is often compared to email: you can use Gmail to send a message to anyone who uses Outlook, Yahoo! Mail, or any other email client, and they can respond back to you. You can even host your own email server.

This is because email is built on top of technical standards that each email client implements. This is the opposite of how typical social media works, with no easy way to connect between different platforms. If you’re on Facebook, you can only talk to other people on Facebook.

Decentralized social media aims to change this, allowing people to build their own communities and still be able to reach their friends who are not part of them.

You might have already heard about Mastodon, which is one of the platforms that make up the fediverse. There are many more, each focused on different aspects of social media. Like Peertube for videos, or Pixelfed for sharing photos. And if you have an account on one of these platforms, you can connect with anyone on the other platforms, much like with email.

How to create a fediverse community

As a community organizer, you have a few options for setting up your community.

  • The creators of the Mastodon platform offer managed hosting for organizations
  • Masto.host is popular service focused on hosting Mastodon servers with data centers located in France. See their pricing page.
  • Fedi Monster: supports Mastodon, Pixelfed, and GoToSocial, but may be periodically closed to new signups
  • toot.io: managed Mastodon hosting
  • Communick: hosting for Mastodon, Lemmy, Funkwhale, and Matrix
  • Hostkey: Mastodon hosting
  • elest.io: multiple platforms, including Mastodon, Pixelfed, Pleroma, Misskey, Sharkey, PeerTube, Friendica, Lemmy, and KBIN

Fediverse platforms are typically open-source, so you can also install them on your own server, see the Mastodon or Pixelfed documentation for an example.

Moderation resources

Moderation in the fediverse is a shared responsibility. Each server sets its own rules and it’s up to the server’s own moderation team to uphold them. Here are some of the tools and resources that you might find helpful.

  • IFTAS: a non-profit initiative that provides guidance to organisations and institutions engaging with the open social web
  • The Fediversalist Papers: study on how governance actually works on the Fediverse
  • Tips for Running a Mastodon Instance (PDF) from Stanford Internet Observatory Cyber Policy Center

Fediverse tools

There is a variety of services and tools that help you automate your social media activity. Given Mastodon’s popularity, most tools integrate primarily with this platform. These include:

  • Buffer, a social media management platform with direct Mastodon support
  • Zoho Social, a social media management platform that also supports Mastodon directly
  • Fedica, a social media management and analytics platform, includes support for Mastodon and Pixelfed
  • Dlvr.it, social media auto poster and scheduler that lets you schedule Mastodon posts
  • Postpone, a social media scheduler that supports Mastodon
  • Publer, a social media management tool that lets you schedule Mastodon posts
  • Pipedream, an automation tool that supports a variety of platforms, including Mastodon

Case studies

The Forkiverse

The Forkiverse is a Mastodon community created by the hosts of the Search Engine and Hard Fork podcasts. Announced as an experiment, it quickly grew to thousands of members over the period of just two weeks.

Good morning Forkiverse! Here's what's #trending this morning:

– A stranger's dog making eye contact with you
– A song you haven't heard in a while playing while you're on shuffle
– Your cup of coffee doesn't leak even a little bit

— Casey Newton (@Casey@theforkiverse.com) 2026-01-10T17:19:42.301Z

#Forkiverse update: we are now at 9,195 registered users 💪

— Casey Newton (@Casey@theforkiverse.com) 2026-01-25T20:51:54.039Z

Read more: The Forkiverse Experiment and Why Instance Choice Matters

Why not the Atmosphere?

Atmosphere is the name of the network that primarily consists of Bluesky, much like the fediverse is made up of Mastodon, Pixelfed, and other fediverse platforms, and uses its own protocol. It is possible to follow accounts between these two networks using the Bridgy Fed project.

While Atmosphere’s stated goal is to achieve decentralization, the current efforts are very limited, with vast majority of the network depending heavily on Bluesky’s own infrastructure. Furthermore, unlike the fediverse, Bluesky relies on venture capital investments to operate, including from a bitcoin and crypto-focused Blockchain Capital. Plus, ads are very likely coming at some point in the future.

See also

  • The world needs social sovereignty, from Mastodon’s official blog
  • The BBC on Mastodon and Extending our Mastodon social media trial: experimenting with distributed and decentralised social media
  • Mastodon for all uni­ver­sity employ­ees: opening the Mastodon service to more than 5,000 employees of the University of Innsbruck
  • Public Broadcasters of Europe, Let’s All Start Microblogging: Innovation Manager at Deutsche Welle (DW), writes about his team’s exceptionally positive experience with microblogging in the Fediverse
  • Thoughts on the first 18 months of running a Mastodon server: experiences of a small community tech studio working in the publicly-funded community sector
  • One year after X: Embracing open science on Mastodon by University of Groningen
  • Fediverse: An overview for government agencies

Fediverse world map via arewedecentralizedyet.online/map.

There were two recent major changes related to alt text to Mastodon. In September last year, the alt text would no longer show up when hovering the image, instead you can click the alt text badge to view the image description in a popup.

And in February of this year, a popup was added with a warning if you try to post an image without alt text. This warning is enabled by default, and can be disabled in settings.

item.title: How to make a website in 5 minutes
item.dc:creator: Stefan Bohacek
item.description: (Or so.)
item.content:encoded:
You probably have a few social media accounts at this point. Instagram, likely? Bluesky, perhaps. Maybe you’ve already joined the fediverse. Maybe you even have a blog, or a SoundCloud. Have you thought about having one place where people can find you that would list all of your online presence?

And did you know that some fediverse platforms let you verify your account with your own website, unlike Bluesky or Twitter/X, where you need to be deemed important enough?

Now, in this tutorial I am not going to convince you that you should learn to code. I certainly encourage you, if that sounds interesting to you, and I have a nice list of resources for that. Instead, I’d like to take you as quickly through setting up a basic personal website as possible.

Ready? Let’s start the timer.

First, you will need to sign up for a neocities.org account, this is where we will host our site, completely for free.

Once you’re logged in, look for the Edit Site button in the top right corner.

This will bring you to the edit page, where you can click on the index.html file to open it.

This will open up the HTML editor with the following HTML code in it.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>The web site of stefan-temp</title>
    <!-- The style.css file allows you to change the look of your web pages.
         If you include the next line in all your web pages, they will all share the same look.
         This makes it easier to make new pages for your site. -->
    <link href="/style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" media="all">
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Welcome to my Website!</h1>

    <p>This is a paragraph! Here's how you make a link: <a href="https://neocities.org">Neocities</a>.</p>

    <p>Here's how you can make <strong>bold</strong> and <em>italic</em> text.</p>

    <p>Here's how you can add an image:</p>
    <img src="/neocities.png" alt="Site hosted by Neocities">

    <p>Here's how to make a list:</p>

    <ul>
      <li>First thing</li>
      <li>Second thing</li>
      <li>Third thing</li>
    </ul>

    <p>To learn more HTML/CSS, check out these <a href="https://neocities.org/tutorials">tutorials</a>!</p>
  </body>
</html>

This is already a solid start. For now we only need to know that HTML, which stands for Hypertext Markup Language, consists of tags, formatted as <tag></tag>, or sometimes just <tag/>. For our first website, we’re going to be working with the following HTML tags.

  • <h1></h1>, a header tag that will show a title of our page
  • <p></p>, which is a paragraph
  • <ul></ul> and <li></li>, which are unsorted list and list item tags, respectively
  • and we’re going to be adding the anchor tag <a></a> for our links

It is also good to be familiar with the <body></body> tag that wraps the visible content of our site, <head></head>, which may include some information about our page that’s mainly for browsers and hidden from us when we visit the page, and finally, the <html></html> tag hat wraps everything.

Still with me? Great. Let’s make some simple updates to the text on the page. Let’s change the text inside the <h1></h1> tag to something more personalized. I’ll go with:

<h1>Welcome to Stefan's website!</h1>

Next, let’s change the text inside the first paragraph to something like this.

<p>Here's where you can find me online!</p>

And we can remove the remaining paragraphs, as well as the <img/> tag. We’ll keep the list, and add the anchor tag I mentioned earlier. This time, we’ll add an href attribute to each tag with URLs of our online profiles. It might look something like this:

<ul>
  <li>
    <a href="https://stefanbohacek.online/@stefan">My Mastodon</a>
  </li>
  <li>
    <a href="https://soundcloud.com/stefanbohacek">My SoundCloud</a>
  </li>
  <li>
    <a href="https://bots.stefanbohacek.com/">My award-winning online bots</a>
  </li>
</ul>

And here’s something neat. Another attribute we can add to the anchor tag is rel="me", this basically says that the link goes to a page that represents us. You can add this to any link, but when you do this with your Mastodon link, and add the link to your page on your Mastodon profile, you’ll get a nice little green verification checkmark. For free!

Here’s what this looks like.

<ul>
  <li>
    <a href="https://stefanbohacek.online/@stefan" rel="me">My Mastodon</a>
  </li>
  <li>
    <a href="https://soundcloud.com/stefanbohacek" rel="me">My SoundCloud</a>
  </li>
  <li>
    <a href="https://bots.stefanbohacek.com/" rel="me">My award-winning online bots</a>
  </li>
</ul>

Here’s everything together.

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>The web site of stefan-temp</title>
    <!-- The style.css file allows you to change the look of your web pages.
         If you include the next line in all your web pages, they will all share the same look.
         This makes it easier to make new pages for your site. -->
    <link href="/style.css" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" media="all">
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Welcome to Stefan's website!</h1>

    <p>Here's where you can find me online!</p>
    
    <ul>
      <li>
        <a href="https://stefanbohacek.online/@stefan">My Mastodon</a>
      </li>
      <li>
        <a href="https://soundcloud.com/stefanbohacek">My SoundCloud</a>
      </li>
      <li>
        <a href="https://bots.stefanbohacek.com/">My award-winning online bots</a>
      </li>
    </ul>

  </body>
</html>

And there you have it, your very own piece of the web. The beauty of it is that your website can look like anything you want it to look. You can put as much effort into it as you want. You can learn to code to improve it, or you can use a drag-and-drop tool. You can make it look sleek, or you can keep it simple, just the way the first website ever made looked.

It’s all up to you.

item.title: Making a free image gallery with 11ty and Neocities.org
item.dc:creator: Stefan Bohacek
item.description: A gentle introduction to static site generators.
item.content:encoded:
Last month I wrote a version of this tutorial aimed at people who prefer a simpler, more straightforward setup for their websites without the need to install extra tools or use a command line. As with everything, there are trade-offs to be considered. In this follow-up, I will revisit the gallery project using 11ty, a popular static site generator. This will make certain things a bit easier, at the expense of some extra work in the beginning.

Going forward, I will assume basic familiarity with command line interfaces, or at least willingness to learn how to use them. (If that is you, I promise it will be a lot easier that it sounds!)

Here’s a look at the finished result on radical-gallery.neocities.org.

Radical indeed!

Much like in the previous tutorial, we will use Neocities to host our site, so you can go ahead and sign up for an account now. To be able to upload the finished gallery automatically, we’ll need to sign up for the $5/month Supporter plan. The free tier will still be sufficient for hosting the site, we’ll just have to upload the site manually.

If all that sounds good, let’s begin!

First, we’ll need to install node.js. If you’re not familiar with it yet, think of it as a way to run JavaScript code on a server, or inside your command line. This is what will let us use 11ty to turn a bunch of files into a website.

Download (or clone) the GitHub repository for this project. We will be working inside the 11ty/base-project folder. Navigate to it using the cd command in the command line. As a quick tip, you can type cd and then drag the folder which you want to open into the command line window to make this step easy.

Let’s install the project’s dependencies using npm install.

If you opted in to become a supporter (kudos to you, you’re helping keep the service free for many of its users!), you can find your API key on the Settings page, link to which is available when you hover, hover over your site’s name in the top-right corner, then switch to the API tab. (Or if you prefer a link: neocities.org/settings/YOURSITENAME#api_key.)

You can save the API key in the .env file. If you’re sticking with the free plan, you can skip this step.

Now for the fun part.

Put the images for your gallery in the images/gallery folder. Next, inside the _data folder, you will find two files:

  • site.json: here you can set up basic information about your site, and
  • images.json: this is where we will build our gallery.

Both of these files are written in a JSON data format. Let’s take a closer look at images.json. Here is a gallery with just one item.

[
  {
    "src": "images/gallery/all-power-to-the-people.jpg",
    "width": 499,
    "height": 613,
    "title": "All power to the people",
    "alt": "A stark black drawing of a raised clenched fist on a white background. The text 'All power to the people' surrounds the fist above and below it.",
    "caption": "<strong>All power to the people (1960s)</strong><br />By Emory Douglas, Black Panther Party's Minister of Culture."
  }  
]

Here we’re describing some basic attributes of our first image, like its source (src) and its dimensions (width and height). Then we have a few description fields, here’s how they are used in the gallery.

The alt text is not shown in the screenshot above as this value is not typically visible, rather it’s the text that’s read out by screen readers or shown if the image fails to load for some reason. (See why this is important.)

We can then add as many of these images, separated by a comma.

[
  {
    "src": "images/gallery/all-power-to-the-people.jpg",
    "width": 499,
    "height": 613,
    "title": "All power to the people",
    "alt": "A stark black drawing of a raised clenched fist on a white background. The text 'All power to the people' surrounds the fist above and below it.",
    "caption": "<strong>All power to the people (1960s)</strong><br />By Emory Douglas, Black Panther Party's Minister of Culture."
  }, 
  {
    "src": "images/gallery/image-2.png",
    "width": 800,
    "height": 1000,
    "title": "Second image title",
    "alt": "Another short description of what's in the image for users of screen readers.",
    "caption": "More details about the second image, like source, or copyright information."
  }
]

And this is the trade-off I was referring to earlier. We can either write the HTML code for the gallery ourselves, as we’ve done in the original tutorial, and which can be a bit more tedious, or we can work with JSON files, which might be easier to read and maintain, but this requires a tool that generates the HTML for us.

Neither approach is better, we’re just making a decision about which workflow works best for our needs.

Once we’re done editing the JSON files, we can go back to the terminal and run a command that will tell 11ty to transform this JSON file into an HTML file with the code for our gallery, and let us access the gallery locally on our computer.

npm start

Once the process finishes, you can open http://localhost:8080/ in your browser and marvel at the fruits of our labor. Well done!

Now, depending on whether you decided to splurge on the paid plan or not, you have two options how to publish your website.

If you are on the paid plan and saved your API key, you can upload your files with:

npm upload

Otherwise you can run the below command to generate the site into the _site folder, and you can then upload the files yourself.

npm build

Alternatively, you can look into the Neocities Command Line Interface (CLI), or set up a GitHub action.

If you’d like to further customize your gallery page, some of the other files and folders to look at are:

  • _includes\layout.njk: this is the main layout file, it mainly contains various meta tags.
  • index.njk: this file contains the base HTML of the page and will be merged with the generated HTML code of the gallery
  • the src folder contains the JavaScript and CSS files

The libs is meant for adding libraries, which is currently only Photoswipe, which is used to present the gallery itself.

Hope you enjoyed this walkthrough, and that you like your new gallery! If you run into any issues, or just want to share what you made, feel free to reach out. Otherwise, until next time!

item.title: Making a free image gallery with Neocities.org
item.dc:creator: Stefan Bohacek
item.description: A third attempt at teaching you how to make a simple image gallery.
item.content:encoded:
Heads-up! There is now a version of this tutorial that uses the 11ty static site generator.

Today I’d like to revisit an older project, making this a third version of the original tutorial, the first two of which are no longer usable as the platform I’ve used has been shut down. Third time’s the charm, they say!

The earlier tutorials took advantage of the platform handling some of the trickier parts of making a website, and I’ve struggled a bit to find a replacement where the workflow would be similarly frictionless.

Having failed that, I will do my best to make the HTML parts of this updated tutorial feel less intimidating. Let’s get to it!

First, have a look at the finished result on radical-gallery.neocities.org.

Pretty neat! And informative, I’d like to hope.

Here are the tools that we will be using today:

  • neocities.org to host our gallery
  • the PhotoSwipe image gallery
  • optionally, your favorite code editor – Notepad will do!
  • our boundless imagination

This project also uses the popular Bootstrap library, but you won’t need to care much about it, it’s there to provide some of the basic styling and an automatic dark mode.

First, let’s sign up for our free Neocities account. The free account is plenty generous for our needs, but hopefully by the end of this tutorial you will consider becoming a supporter, both to enjoy larger storage limits for your gallery, the option of making multiple websites under the same account, and a good feeling about supporting a really great project.

With your account set up, head over to this GitHub page and download the code that we’ll be using as the basis of our gallery.

Once you have the project files downloaded and open, you will see the base-project folder, make a copy of it, naming it appropriately. (my-gallery is a good option for now!)

First, let’s put our images inside the images/gallery folder. You can safely delete the placeholder file I left here.

Now we have a few options how to edit the code. You can upload the files to Neocities now (look out for the Edit Site button on top of the page, on your right), or you can use your favorite code editor.

If you decide to edit your files on Neocities, your should look like this after you drag in the contents of your gallery folder:

Next, open the index.html file and look for this section:

<!--
Your gallery will consist of repeated blocks of code for each slide:

<div class="pswp-gallery__item">
  <a href="images/gallery/FILE.PNG"
    data-pswp-width="width of your image in pixels"
    data-pswp-height="height of your image in pixels"
    target="_blank">
    <img src="images/gallery/FILE.PNG"
      title="A short, descriptive title of your image."
      alt="A brief, detailed explanation of what is in your image." />
    <div class="pswp-caption-content">
      A caption for your image.
    </div>
  </a>
</div>      
-->

You can remove the <!-- and --> parts, which, if you’re not familiar with this yet, are used to mark a comment in HTML that will not be visible in the browser, as well as the instruction text.

This will leave you with the HTML code for a single gallery slide.

<div class="pswp-gallery__item">
  <a href="images/gallery/FILE.PNG"
    data-pswp-width="width of your image in pixels"
    data-pswp-height="height of your image in pixels"
    target="_blank">
    <img src="images/gallery/FILE.PNG"
      title="A short, descriptive title of your image."
      alt="A brief, detailed explanation of what is in your image." />
    <div class="pswp-caption-content">
      A caption for your image.
    </div>
  </a>
</div>

At this point, we are actually pretty far along! Let’s update this block to show the first image in our gallery. Here’s the finished snippet, I will walk you through what all of this means in just a moment.

<div class="pswp-gallery__item">
  <a href="images/gallery/all-power-to-the-people.jpg"
    data-pswp-width="499"
    data-pswp-height="613"
    target="_blank">
    <img src="images/gallery/all-power-to-the-people.jpg"
      title="All power to the people"
      alt="A stark black drawing of a raised clenched fist on a white background. The text 'All power to the people' surrounds the fist above and below it." />
    <div class="pswp-caption-content">
      <strong>
        All power to the people (1960s)
      </strong>
      <br />
      By Emory Douglas, Black Panther Party's Minister of Culture.
    </div>
  </a>
</div>

Here is what I updated:

  • I set data-pswp-width to 499 and data-pswp-height to 613, which are the width and the height of my first image, 499px and 613px respectively.
  • I updated the src attribute of the img tag to point to my first image inside the images/galley folder.
  • I also set the alt and title attribute of our image. The difference here is that alt describes what the content of the image looks like, which is useful for accessibility, and the title can be short and shows up when you hover the image.
    • You can learn more about image tags on MDN.
  • I am using a few extra HTML elements inside the pswp-caption-content section, namely <strong> and <br />, but you can keep this simple and just write the text you want to use here.

And that’s it! Now you can copy this block as many times as you need, one for each slide in your gallery. You can see a finished example back in the project’s repo.

Now for some finishing touches.

  • Update the <title> tag to show a title of your gallery. Same with the <h1> tag.
  • Update the intro text inside the <p> tag before your gallery. Or you can remove it, if you prefer.
  • Similarly, update or remove the text in your <footer>.
  • And if you have a fediverse account, here’s how you can add verification to your gallery page.

If you’ve been using a coding editor, you can now upload your gallery files to Neocities and view it at NAME_OF_YOUR_SITE.neocities.org To find the link, use the View Site button if you’re using the editor, or you’ll see it above the site file manager interface.

There is so much you can do with your site and you can find some resources to get you started in my blog post.

Hope you enjoyed this brief walkthrough! If you get stuck, or have any questions, feel free to reach out!

Until next time!

item.title: On celebrating small wins during autocracy
item.dc:creator: Stefan Bohacek
item.description: Small things can make a big difference.
item.content:encoded:
It is a bit of a cliché to talk about how time flies, but looking back at 2015, when I created Botwiki, it sure feels like a whole different era.

Sure, some will argue that we’ve been on the path to where we are now for a very long time, and I can’t really disagree with that much. But the bottom line is, 10 years of eroding rights is now leaving a mark.

So, how does one celebrate small victories with so many of us losing so much? How do you share small joys with a world full of senseless suffering?

I know everyone reading this will have their own answer. And I know the old wisdom “read the room” is a good one to follow, always.

But perhaps this seemingly unresolvable conflict does have a resolution: you help fight the darkness by bringing a little bit of positivity into the world. If we all do, it will add up.

We still need to be able to laugh and celebrate, and most importantly, build communities.

And that is, in great part, what I set out to do with Botwiki and Botmakers 10 years ago: to dedicate a small part of the internet to learning about creative automation, and find inspiration, and a community to share your own work with.

And admittedly, the interest in making little online bots has faded over time. But I am very proud of the work I’ve done, with the help of so many others, and what we’ve created together, and want to celebrate all of that. And maybe inspire you, dear reader, to give creative botmaking (another) try.

Because small things can still make a difference in someone’s life.

item.title: On generative AI and LLMs
item.dc:creator: Stefan Bohacek
item.description: Generative AI is anti-worker, anti-environment, and doesn't even work all that well.
item.content:encoded:
When generative AI and large language models (LLMs) work, or appear to work, using them truly feels like magic. They can be very empowering, especially when used as an accessibility tool.

But they are also an unreliable technology built on exploitation of workers, particularly from third world countries, and our environment. Its frequent use may lead to cognitive decline and a loss of skills, and can actually decrease productivity.

Below is a selection of articles and studies that should serve as a reminder to approach any new technology with critical thinking and carefully weigh its benefits against its true costs.

What trade-offs are you willing to make?

  • Environmental impact
  • Workers’ rights
  • Reliability and productivity
  • Cognitive skills and mental health
  • Consumer sentiment
  • Further reading

Environmental impact

The environmental impact of artificial intelligence includes substantial electricity consumption for training and using deep learning models, and the related carbon footprint and water usage.[1] Moreover, the artificial intelligence (AI) data centers are materially intense, requiring a large amount of electronics that use specialized mined metals and which eventually will be disposed as e-waste.

wikipedia.org

AI data center electricity demand revives peaker power plants. Peakers emit more pollution when they run than typical power plants. The power plants are often located in low-income, minority communities.

reuters.com

In South Memphis, Tennessee, a neighborhood called Boxtown is paying the price for the AI revolution with every breath. This historically Black community, founded by formerly enslaved people who built homes from discarded railroad boxcars, now faces a new threat: massive gas-powered generators installed by xAI — Elon Musk’s artificial intelligence company — that are poisoning their air.

techpolicy.press

On Monday, court documents revealed that AI company Anthropic spent millions of dollars physically scanning print books to build Claude, an AI assistant similar to ChatGPT. In the process, the company cut millions of print books from their bindings, scanned them into digital files, and threw away the originals solely for the purpose of training AI—details buried in a copyright ruling on fair use whose broader fair use implications we reported yesterday.

arstechnica.com

Workers’ rights

A new global study shows that AI adoption varies by seniority, with 87% of executives using it on the job, compared with 57% of managers and 27% of employees.

businessinsider.com

Artificial intelligence is coming for your job: 41% of employers intend to downsize their workforce as AI automates certain tasks, a World Economic Forum survey showed Wednesday.

cnn.com

There’s a growing global army of millions toiling to make AI run smoothly. They’re called “humans in the loop:” people sorting, labeling, and sifting reams of data to train and improve AI for companies like Meta, OpenAI, Microsoft and Google. It’s gruntwork that needs to be done accurately, fast, and – to do it cheaply – it’s often farmed out to places like Africa.

cbsnews.com

As policy makers in the UK weigh how to regulate the AI industry, Nick Clegg, former UK deputy prime minister and former Meta executive, claimed a push for artist consent would “basically kill” the AI industry.

theverge.com

The developer OpenAI has said it would be impossible to create tools like its groundbreaking chatbot ChatGPT without access to copyrighted material, as pressure grows on artificial intelligence firms over the content used to train their products.

theguardian.com

Multiple artificial intelligence companies are circumventing a common web standard used by publishers to block the scraping of their content for use in generative AI systems, content licensing startup TollBit has told publishers.

reuters.com

Reliability and productivity

New research coordinated by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) and led by the BBC has found that AI assistants – already a daily information gateway for millions of people – routinely misrepresent news content no matter which language, territory, or AI platform is tested.

bbc.co.uk

The researchers tested eight AI-driven search tools by providing direct excerpts from real news articles and asking the models to identify each article’s original headline, publisher, publication date, and URL. They discovered that the AI models incorrectly cited sources in more than 60 percent of these queries, raising significant concerns about their reliability in correctly attributing news content.

arstechnica.com

The errors made by chatbots, known as “hallucinations”, have been a problem from the start, and it is becoming clear we may never get rid of them.

newscientist.com

OpenAI, the creator of ChatGPT, acknowledged in its own research that large language models will always produce hallucinations due to fundamental mathematical constraints that cannot be solved through better engineering, marking a significant admission from one of the AI industry’s leading companies.

computerworld.com

Consider, for instance, that the number of companies with fully AI-led processes nearly doubled last year, while AI use has likewise doubled at work since 2023. Yet a recent report from the MIT Media Lab found that 95% of organizations see no measurable return on their investment in these technologies. So much activity, so much enthusiasm, so little return.

hbr.org

A study of high school students using ChatGPT to practice math problems or to be tutored in math did worse on a test than students who learned the old-fashioned way. The issue seems to have been a combination of students learning differently when using AI, and the fact that the AI tools gave wrong instructions or answers.

insights.taylorduma.com

A paper by researchers at the University of Oxford found that while LLMs could correctly identify relevant conditions 94.9% of the time when directly presented with test scenarios, human participants using LLMs to diagnose the same scenarios identified the correct conditions less than 34.5% of the time.

venturebeat.com

The 2025 survey of over 49,000 developers across 177 countries reveals a troubling paradox in enterprise AI adoption. AI usage continues climbing—84% of developers now use or plan to use AI tools, up from 76% in 2024. Yet trust in these tools has cratered.

[…]

Only 33% of developers trust AI accuracy in 2025, down from 43% in 2024 and 42% in 2023. AI favorability dropped from 77% in 2023 to 72% in 2024 to just 60% this year.

venturebeat.com

Adding to the reality check, a new report by AI software company CodeRabbit found that code generated by an AI was far more error-prone than the human-written stuff — and by a significant margin. Across the 470 pull requests the company analyzed, AI code produced an average 10.83 issues per request, while human-authored code produced just 6.45.

futurism.com

Many developers say AI coding assistants make them more productive, but a recent study set forth to measure their output and found no significant gains. Use of GitHub Copilot also introduced 41% more bugs, according to the study from Uplevel, a company providing insights from coding and collaboration data.

cio.com

More developers actively distrust the accuracy of AI tools (46%) than trust it (33%), and only a fraction (3%) report “highly trusting” the output. Experienced developers are the most cautious, with the lowest “highly trust” rate (2.6%) and the highest “highly distrust” rate (20%), indicating a widespread need for human verification for those in roles with accountability.

survey.stackoverflow.co

My argument: If so many developers are so extraordinarily productive using these tools, where is the flood of shovelware? We should be seeing apps of all shapes and sizes, video games, new websites, mobile apps, software-as-a-service apps — we should be drowning in choice. We should be in the middle of an indie software revolution. We should be seeing 10,000 Tetris clones on Steam.

mikelovesrobots.substack.com

Two-thirds of nonmanagement staffers said they saved less than two hours a week or no time at all with AI. More than 40% of executives, in contrast, said the technology saved them more than eight hours of work a week.

wsj.com

Cognitive skills and mental health

However, alongside the seemingly limitless capabilities of ChatGPT and friends, we find a less-discussed consequence: the gradual decline of human cognitive skills. Unlike earlier tools such as calculators and spreadsheets, which made specific tasks easier without fundamentally altering our ability to think, AI is reshaping the way we process information and make decisions, often diminishing our reliance on our own cognitive abilities.
